segment.source: App-to-app communication
segment.target: App-to-app communication

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This section explains how to share data between Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps, including how to use the Share contract, copy and paste, and drag and drop.
segment.target: This section explains how to share data between Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps, including how to use the Share contract, copy and paste, and drag and drop.

segment.source: The Share contract is one way users can quickly exchange data between apps.
segment.target: The Share contract is one way users can quickly exchange data between apps.

segment.source: For example, a user might want to share a webpage with their friends using a social networking app, or save a link in a notes app to refer to later.
segment.target: For example, a user might want to share a webpage with their friends using a social networking app, or save a link in a notes app to refer to later.

segment.source: Consider using a Share contract if your app receives content in scenarios that a user can quickly complete while in the context of another app.
segment.target: Consider using a Share contract if your app receives content in scenarios that a user can quickly complete while in the context of another app.

segment.source: An app can support the Share feature in two ways.
segment.target: An app can support the Share feature in two ways.

segment.source: First, it can be a source app that provides content that the user wants to share.
segment.target: First, it can be a source app that provides content that the user wants to share.

segment.source: Second, the app can be a target app that the user selects as the destination for shared content.
segment.target: Second, the app can be a target app that the user selects as the destination for shared content.

segment.source: An app can also be both a source app and a target app.
segment.target: An app can also be both a source app and a target app.

segment.source: If you want your app to share content as a source app, you need to decide what data formats your app can provide.
segment.target: If you want your app to share content as a source app, you need to decide what data formats your app can provide.

segment.source: In addition to the Share contract, apps can also integrate classic techniques for transferring data, such as dragging and dropping or copy and pasting.
segment.target: In addition to the Share contract, apps can also integrate classic techniques for transferring data, such as dragging and dropping or copy and pasting.

segment.source: In addition to communication between UWP apps, these methods also support sharing to and from desktop applications.
segment.target: In addition to communication between UWP apps, these methods also support sharing to and from desktop applications.

segment.source: In this section
segment.target: In this section

segment.source: Topic
segment.target: Topic

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: This article explains how to support the Share contract in a UWP app.
segment.target: This article explains how to support the Share contract in a UWP app.

segment.source: The Share contract is an easy way to quickly share data, such as text, links, photos, and videos, between apps.
segment.target: The Share contract is an easy way to quickly share data, such as text, links, photos, and videos, between apps.

segment.source: For example, a user might want to share a webpage with their friends using a social networking app, or save a link in a notes app to refer to later.
segment.target: For example, a user might want to share a webpage with their friends using a social networking app, or save a link in a notes app to refer to later.

segment.source: This article explains how to receive content in your UWP app shared from another app using Share contract.
segment.target: This article explains how to receive content in your UWP app shared from another app using Share contract.

segment.source: This Share contract allows your app to be presented as an option when the user invokes Share.
segment.target: This Share contract allows your app to be presented as an option when the user invokes Share.

segment.source: This article explains how to support copy and paste in UWP apps using the clipboard.
segment.target: This article explains how to support copy and paste in UWP apps using the clipboard.

segment.source: Copy and paste is the classic way to exchange data either between apps, or within an app, and almost every app can support clipboard operations to some degree.
segment.target: Copy and paste is the classic way to exchange data either between apps, or within an app, and almost every app can support clipboard operations to some degree.

segment.source: This article explains how to add dragging and dropping in your UWP app.
segment.target: This article explains how to add dragging and dropping in your UWP app.

segment.source: Drag and drop is a classic, natural way of interacting with content such as images and files.
segment.target: Drag and drop is a classic, natural way of interacting with content such as images and files.

segment.source: Once implemented, drag and drop works seamlessly in all directions, including app-to-app, app-to-desktop, and desktop-to app.
segment.target: Once implemented, drag and drop works seamlessly in all directions, including app-to-app, app-to-desktop, and desktop-to app.
